content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim"> <record>   <controlfield tag="001">14826</controlfield>   <controlfield tag="005">20150205103416.0</controlfield>   <datafield tag="856" ind1="4" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="s">844250</subfield>     <subfield code="u">https://zenodo.org/record/14826/files/Robele_Gari_et_al_2014.pdf</subfield>     <subfield code="z">0</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="c">308392</subfield>     <subfield code="a">DEVOTES - DEVelopment Of innovative Tools for understanding marine biodiversity and assessing good Environmental Status (308392)</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">Driver-pressure-state-impact-response</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">Social-ecological systems</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">Coasts</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="700" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">NILU-IMPEC, Box 100, 2027 Kjeller, Norway</subfield>     <subfield code="a">Newton, Alice</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="700" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">CIMA-University of Algarve, Gambelas Campus, 8005-139 Faro, Portugal</subfield>     <subfield code="a">Icely, John D. </subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="245" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">A review of the application and evolution of the DPSIR framework with an emphasis on coastal social-ecological systems</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="542" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="l">open</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a"><p><strong>Abstract</strong></p>  <p>The applications of the Driver-Pressure-State-Impact-Response (DPSIR) framework were reviewed for several Social-Ecological Systems (SES), with an emphasis on the coastal environment. The evolution of DPSIR was traced from the Stress-Response framework to its present form. Discrepancies in the definitions of the DPSIR&#39;s information categories are presented. The application of the framework was explored both as a discrete tool and combined with other methods for different coastal and estuarine systems and biodiversity. The overall merits and limitations of the DPSIR framework are discussed in a critique. Several recommendations are suggested for refining the framework to overcome its limitations. Finally it is concluded that an updated DPSIR framework is a useful adaptive management tool for analyzing and identifying solutions to environmental problems.</p></subfield>   </datafield>
